Wow, you're proly all like that's like all Larry does is talk about Canada, but this is only my second post about it. I just can't explain what it's like. If I told you what we did, most of you would prolly ask.... "Well why do you go back every year?". And if I knew the answer to that question, I'd tell ya. But there is something unique, something different, something extrodinary about it that just keeps bringing me back. Its not the never ending lake, its not those millons of stars, but what I think it is is the peacefulness. The relaxation. The cameraderie. But most of all it's the atmosphere. When you wake up in the morning, you don't have to worry about who is going to like you and who is going to be mad. You don't have to worry about your boyfriend or girlfriend. You don't have to worry about fitting in. You don't have to worry about how you look. When your biggest problem is a 220 rod portage, life is good... very good (especially if its Yum Yum (haha Canada kids)(I hear its over rated anyway)). Life, I think it's good.

The reason this blog is titled "A unique outlook" is due to one of my favorite teacher in the entire world, Mr. Kuhn. Kuhn is absolutely the man, and anyone who has had him will tell you that. But, anyway, back to my story. We were talking one day and he told me that I was the only kid that he knew who was truly happy... that all of the other kids took things for granted and were just down sometimes. He asked me why that was and I told him what I thought to be a good answer. "Well K-Man, I'm a 15 year-old highschool Freshman. There is nothing in my life, right now, that big, that I can be truly that upset about." And he said, "You're right, Larry. It's just that most kids your age don't figure that out for awhile." That moment is probably one of the most defining moments of my life. I try and be open minded and see the entire spectrum of things. Always be positive, never get down. I have a unique outlook on life... it cannot be explained in words.

Every year I go on a canoeing and camping trip to Quetico Provincial Park, in Canada (just above Minnesota). It the most amazing place I have ever been to. Trees as far as the eye can see. Canoeing down endless lakes. Singing ridiculous songs to your fellow canoers. Lakes ending, portages beginning. Searching for campsites. Setting up tents. Hanging the close line. R and R. Chopping fire wood. Coooking a nice dinner over a warm fire. Euchre game. Massages and rest. A look at the stars. The stars that never end. Hundreds of thousands that you could reach out and touch. Crawling into the sleeping bag. Drifting into a different land. Awaking to the sounds of the loon. Another day gone, another day about to begin. urlLink Getting up for an early paddle, the sunset was beautiful. Had to stop and take a photo. urlLink

Yes, another adventure for me. My partner in crime this time, Allison Douglas. Well all these adventures seem to start off the same, we were bored and had nothing to do. So Allison wanted to go jump in a pond and I didn't want to... cuz I'm supposed to do that with Ryan and Jordan, but that's for another blog. Anyway, so she ran upstairs and outside and chased her down and then we saw the mini-bike. Now this isn't any ordinary moped type thing, this thing is the coolest little motorcycle ever. It's a 1970 honda mini-trail, blue with orange writing. Oh so pimp. It goes about 15 mph, on a good day. But, back to the adventure. I got on the mini-bike and Allison got on my bike and we meandered down the street, with no particular place in mind. It was about 8 o' clock when we left and rode down my street then around in circles for awhile, then down the Ciceros street, then back. Down another street, on to the golf cart path, past the hole in one hole, and down by the Pyle's house. We rode up their back yard to say hi, but almost got attacked by their dogs in the process. They weren't home so it was back to the cart path, and Allison was driving the mini-bike. Oh boy, there's someting scary. She didn't even know where the brake was. Oh geeze. But, we drove around for awhile, down the cart path to the seventeenth hole where we found the sprinklers. YES! Gotta love the sprinklers. So we drove through them a little bit, and then turned around, back past the Pyle's house and down to the DeJong's house. They are in Wisconsin so we jumped on their trampolene for awhile. We layed there and Allison said, "lets go get ice cream." So off we went. Back down the cart path, through the sprinklers, on to the 18th hole. Off the 18th past the tennis courts and down to the office park through the secret maintenence path on to the 9th hole, past the Wises and up the huge hill. Down through the Villas and out by Wells Fargo and McDonalds, our destination. Wow, what top quality individuals they have working there. But aside from that, Allison got a triple thick milkshake, and I got a hot fudge sunday. We ate/drank our ice cream and looked at our phones. the time was 8:59 and I bet her we could get home in 15 minutes, which is making pretty good time. We ran out the door and onto our bikes. I manned the mini-bike and flipped on the headlights, Allison took the bike. All the way back through our route. Out the Wells Fargo parking lot, back through the Villas down the 9th hole hill, past the Wises, past the club house (close call), on to the open road, back past the driving range, onto the 10th hole. Down the 10th across the street to the hole in one hole, backwards down that hole, back across the street to the 13th (the one my house is on), all the way down the 13th to my back yard. And into my garage... all in 12 minutes. Oh yea, record time. Another adventure in the books. Gotta love it. Live in the moment.

It all started when Ryan and I were sitting in my room with nothing to do. Jenna Wise had just left and we were left alone. We went upstairs and started annoying my parents... and in the words of my father, "Get out and ride your bike or something." So that's what we did. And our adventure began. And so it was... about 10:04 when we embarked on this epic journey. AT first our goal was ice cream... at the local DQ, but then a tasty buger from McDonald's became our new objective (really because we didn't wanna cross 14). With only 12 dollars, a few candy wrappers, and my wallet full of crap in our pockets, we set out for that burger. The time 10:16 p.m. when we arrived at McDonalds. Lights were still on and the hours on the door said they were open 'till 11. But as it turns out that the little black guy inside was closing early, about 45 minutes early. So, I stared him down, as Ryan watched in dismay. He eventually backed while I still rapped on the window. So I was a little cheesed off at McDonalds, which obviously isn't Wendy's, where you can eat great, even late... cuz it wasn't even late yet. But anyway, so Ryan had brilliant revalation - chili dogs at DQ. We crossed 14 and made it to our new destination only to find a killer deal, 2 chili dogs for 2.22. So we bought 4, and 2 small drinks... and those drinks were expensive... I'm talking like 2 bugs a piece, for like 16 ounces.. yea it was bull crap, but anyway. The lady asked us if we wanted to donate a dollar to charity, and we were already running low on money... but luckily Ryan spoke up and of course we donated a dollar. In return, we have cool little cone with our names no it on the wall at DQ. Our chili came out, all nice a neat on the tray, and we being the adventurous type decided to eat outside. After Ryan spilling chili dog all over himself we threw away our trash and were going to go back inside to give the tray back... but the doors were locked. So I proceeded to do a little dance outside the door to get the lady to come over and take the tray. Finally she did and we were off.... we set out for home. It was now about 10:37 and we thought we were going home, until gas station candy caleld our name. We were now down to 3 dollars and 70 cents... but luckily gas station is very fairly priced. A king size Resse's and a box of mild duds, and we were down to to 95 cents. Not too shabby. So finally we were settin out for home, but not before another pit stop. It was now 10:48 and were riding back down the cart paths in the complete dark. And there is this huge hill that we couldn't really see... but we got down that ok. Our final pit stop was the Wise's house. As we proceeded to their door we saw Mrs. Wise really high window in the front. She was hanging some picture or something, but we went in to see if Jordan was home yet. Mr. Wise said he was just leaving to pick him up. So Ryan and I went into the computer room and talked to Jenna for a little bit, then Jordan came home. He kinda poked his head into the computer room with a little grunt, "oh hey... you guys are here.." and proceeded to go upstairs. so we left. And treked backwards down the golf course back to my back yard.
